ProposalInformation.Title: CAR_NIRCAM-0035: NIRCAM Ice Measurement
ProposalInformation.Abstract:
This activity will use NIRCam longwave grism spectra to check for ice contamination associated with the telescope and instrument cooldown. In addition to these NIRCam observations, one observation with NIRSpec will be obtained and analyzed prior to the cryocooler State 4 decision point. Spectra of a stellar target will be used to establish a baseline of any ice contamination on all optical surfaces along the entire OTE plus the NIRCam longwave channel and the NIRSpec IFU channel. These measurements will be taken periodically from early OTE commissioning until the MIRI contamination control cover (CCC) is opened and will be primary considerations for three major decision points: 1) the decision to turn off the FSM heater, 2) the decision to transition the cryocooler to JT bypass mode (State 4), and 3) the decision to open the MIRI CCC. Observations will be divided into three stages, and will be interspersed between OTE alignment activities. To the extent possible, observations should be timed to occur at times when the OTE alignment data is being processed on the ground. The nominal plan calls for at least 9 NIRCam observations, one occurring with the FSM warm, 6 with the FSM cold, but before the transition to cryocooler state four, and two occurring before post-MIMF, but before the CCC opening decision. These final two NIRCam measurements will be paired with additional NIRSpec IFU measurements.
Water ice has a broad absorption band that spans 2.9-3.3 µm. Solar-type stars are quite featureless in the infrared so are excellent for this type of study (e.g., Rayner, Cushing, & Vacca 2009, ApJS 185, 289). We therefore plan to observe G2 dwarf stars for the majority of these observations. Where G2 stars are not available, featureless stars such as K dwarfs and/or A0V stars will be observed. The 2 observations which will be conducted immediately prior to the State 4 decision point and immediately prior to the MIRI cover opening will require faint targets (Vmag >12) ( this is due to the nature of the coordinated NIRCam/NIRSpec observations). This limit should be considered in target selection, as it is preferable for the same target to be used for all observations after the FSM heater is turned off.
The NIRCam grism mode is slitless and a 256 subarray image will be acquired. High precision pointing is not necessary; the broad 3.1 absorption feature and sufficient adjacent continuum can be acquired with a pointing tolerance of 200 pixels in each axis. The grisms are slitless which will accommodate the pointing performance expected in the early stages of OTE commissioning. NIRCam observations will be taken with the 256 subarray to allow for observations of bright targets required while the FSM is still warm and has a high background. The nominal source position on module A is (1024,1800) with a pointing tolerance of 200 pixels in each axis. When ice monitoring observations are taken before PMSA image stacking, multiple PMSA segments are permitted on the array as long as one or more of the spectra are non-overlapping.
These measurements will be conducted in three stages. Due to the constraint preventing using the FSM heater once this mirror goes cold (<120K), the first stage will be obtaining one measurement while the heater is still on to assure there is not unexpected ice absorption. The first opportunity for these observations after launch will be after the NIRCam longwave channel reaches its operational temperature (85K) and performs its initial checkouts. These observations will be taken on a bright G2V star.
After the FSM heater is turned off a series of 6 NIRCam observations (Stage 2) will be taken using a fainter star to accommodate the stacked telescope PSF. These observations will be used to trend water ice accumulation in order to ensure a safe environment for MIRI cooling and ultimately opening the CCC. MIRI is cryocooled and cannot easily be safely warmed up for ice decontamination. Preventing ice contamination is essential for MIRI’s scientific performance. These observations will be coordinated with the OTE wavefront activities. Finally, a third series of observations (Stage 3) will be taken using both NIRCam and NIRSpec: one set of NIRCAM/NIRSpec observations taken just prior to State 4 decision point and the other a few days before the decision to open the CCC. These NIRCam and NIRSpec observations may require another even fainter target. NIRSpec observations will be made with the IFU + PRISM/Clear configuration. The purpose of these observations is to check the NIRSpec optical path in addition to the NIRCam optical path, which can be used to determine if any observed water ice is internal to the instrument, or is on a common optical path (e.g., upstream on the OTE optics).
The measured spectrum depends upon both the stellar source spectrum and the instrument profile. The largest uncertainty in the measurements is likely to be the determination of the stellar continuum so we suggest observing the same source, or at least stellar type, so that the differential equivalent width of the ice absorption feature can be assessed with the greatest precision (+/- 0.4nm) Observations should be made of the same stars if possible—bright stars (K<7) for the unstacked PMSA case (i.e., the first two observations done prior to FSM heater turn off) and a fainter (K>10) star for later measurements following PMSA image stacking. For the combined NIRSpec/NIRCam measurements a third still fainter target may need to be used. The observed PSF will also vary between measurements as the alignment state is improved during commissioning however we expect this to be less of an impact to precision.
The exact timing of ice observations will be coordinated with the wavefront team during OTE commissioning. Nominally observations should be made at regular intervals no closer together than 2 days. Observations will be timed to occur during the analysis periods in OTE commissioning. Table 1 lists a possible timeline of the ice monitoring observations. Please note that this is only a ‘suggested’ schedule of observations, and can be adjusted as needed. Some OTE phases have multiple possible PMSA states, depending on when observations are made. Target selection should be made accordingly. Where possible Observations should be made during ground analysis periods within OTE activities. Activities with specified Ground Analysis periods in the timeline are noted with an ‘*’ in the nominal observation plan. The procedure for executing Ice Monitoring observations must include coordination with the Timeline Coordinator, NIRCam and NIRSpec instrument teams, MOM, Project Science team and Wavefront team. The equivalent width (EW) of the 3.1µm water ice feature will be measured for each observation and the differential measurements will be used to determine the rate of ice accumulation. If projected EOL 3.1µm equivalent width is beyond the contamination control plan requirements, the Anomaly Response Team will decide what contingency activities should be pursued per the Cooldown Plan (JWST-PLAN-034396).
ProposalInformation.ObservingDescription:
Sep. 2021 submission, J. Stansberry ------------------------------------- NOTE: This submission includes 4 new observations (#s 31 - 34), and numerous tweaks to observing parameters in existing observations, per discussions held 2021-08-27. Due to switching to PCS_Mode=COARSE in more observations, the total duration for this submission is ~10 min shortre than the version submitted in April. Details below.
REVIEW OF TARGET VISIBILITY for assumed 2021-12-15 launch. Target Changes:
Obs. 1 + (22 - 26), 2 - 4: Switched to OTE-01 target, HD 84406, G5 K= 4.7 to avoid numerous large slews between early OTE activities and iterations 1 - 4 of NRC-35. This target also has visibility from mid-Jan through late Apr.
Obs. 5: Changed to BD+86 189 for visibility. Obs. 6: Changed to TYC 8558-1141-1 for visibility.
NEW OBSERVATIONS (#s 31 - 34):
These were added to provide a check on pointing-drift over the ~2days between the closest preceding observation in LOS-02, and a check on background levels from the still-warm FSM, and the first iteration of NRC-35. Because they are executed in PCS_Mode=COARSE they are very efficient, requiring about 40 minutes in total.
These should be scheduled ~6 - 8 hours prior to the existing 1st occurrence of NRC-35.1.
OTHER CHANGES:
Switched to FULL from SUBGRISM256 for observations 2, 3 & 4. This allows us to sample multiple PMSA images, and in particular for Obs. 4 to get spectra from the 2 extreme-V3 PMSA segments in a single observation. Exposure params were adjusted accordingly.
PCS_Mode = COARSE for observations up through NRC-35.6 (TRACK was used for some of the later ones, previously). Removed Segment Guide Star SR from NRC-35.4.
Removed the contingency observation #10. We can re-create that trivially if needed.
---------------------------------------
----------- Original (c. 20??) CAR Doc ----------------- ACTIVITY TITLE: NIRCam & NIRSpec Ice Measurements
ID: CAR_NIRCAM-0035
DESCRIPTION: This activity will use NIRCam longwave grism spectra to check for ice contamination associated with the telescope and instrument cooldown. In addition to these NIRCam observations, one observation with NIRSpec will be obtained and analyzed prior to the cryocooler State 4 decision point. Spectra of a stellar target will be used to establish a baseline of any ice contamination on all optical surfaces along the entire OTE plus the NIRCam longwave channel and the NIRSpec IFU channel. These measurements will be taken periodically from early OTE commissioning until the MIRI contamination control cover (CCC) is opened and will be primary considerations for three major decision points: 1) the decision to turn off the FSM heater, 2) the decision to transition the cryocooler to JT bypass mode (State 4), and 3) the decision to open the MIRI CCC. Observations will be divided into three stages, and will be interspersed between OTE alignment activities. To the extent possible, observations should be timed to occur at times when the OTE alignment data is being processed on the ground. The nominal plan calls for at least 9 NIRCam observations, one occurring with the FSM warm, 6 with the FSM cold, but before the transition to cryocooler state four, and two occurring before post-MIMF, but before the CCC opening decision. These final two NIRCam measurements will be paired with additional NIRSpec IFU measurements.
Water ice has a broad absorption band that spans 2.9-3.3 µm. Solar-type stars are quite featureless in the infrared so are excellent for this type of study (e.g., Rayner, Cushing, & Vacca 2009, ApJS 185, 289). We therefore plan to observe G2 dwarf stars for the majority of these observations. Where G2 stars are not available, featureless stars such as K dwarfs and/or A0V stars will be observed. The 2 observations which will be conducted immediately prior to the State 4 decision point and immediately prior to the MIRI cover opening will require faint targets (Vmag ~12) ( this is due to the nature of the coordinated NIRCam/NIRSpec observations). This limit should be considered in target selection, as it is preferable for the same target to be used for all observations after the FSM heater is turned off.
The NIRCam grism mode is slitless and a 256 subarray image will be acquired. High precision pointing is not necessary; the broad 3.1 absorption feature and sufficient adjacent continuum can be acquired with a pointing tolerance of 200 pixels in each axis. The grisms are slitless which will accommodate the pointing performance expected in the early stages of OTE commissioning. NIRCam observations will be taken with the 256 subarray to allow for observations of bright targets required while the FSM is still warm and has a high background. The nominal source position on module A is (1024,1800) with a pointing tolerance of 200 pixels in each axis. When ice monitoring observations are taken before PMSA image stacking, multiple PMSA segments are permitted on the array as long as one or more of the spectra are non-overlapping.
These measurements will be conducted in three stages. Due to the constraint preventing using the FSM heater once this mirror goes cold (<120K), the first stage will be obtaining one measurement while the heater is still on to assure there is not unexpected ice absorption. The first opportunity for this observation after launch will be after the NIRCam longwave channel reaches its operational temperature (85K) and performs its initial checkouts. This observation will be taken on a bright G2V star. If there is an issue with this measurement, a contingency measurement can done. This is in the APT as observation 10, but is only a contingency.
After the FSM heater is turned off a series of 6 NIRCam observations (Stage 2) will be taken using a fainter star to accommodate the stacked telescope PSF. These observations will be used to trend water ice accumulation in order to ensure a safe environment for MIRI cooling and ultimately opening the CCC. MIRI is cryocooled and cannot easily be safely warmed up for ice decontamination. Preventing ice contamination is essential for MIRI’s scientific performance. These observations will be coordinated with the OTE wavefront activities. Finally, a third series of observations (Stage 3) will be taken using both NIRCam and NIRSpec: one set of NIRCAM/NIRSpec observations taken just prior to State 4 decision point and the other a few days before the decision to open the CCC. These NIRCam and NIRSpec observations may require another even fainter target. NIRSpec observations will be made with the IFU + PRISM/Clear configuration. The purpose of these observations is to check the NIRSpec optical path in addition to the NIRCam optical path, which can be used to determine if any observed water ice is internal to the instrument, or is on a common optical path (e.g., upstream on the OTE optics).
The measured spectrum depends upon both the stellar source spectrum and the instrument profile. The largest uncertainty in the measurements is likely to be the determination of the stellar continuum so we suggest observing the same source, or at least stellar type, so that the differential equivalent width of the ice absorption feature can be assessed with the greatest precision (+/- 0.4nm) Observations should be made of the same stars if possible—bright stars (K<7) for the unstacked PMSA case (i.e., the first two observations done prior to FSM heater turn off) and a fainter (K>10) star for later measurements following PMSA image stacking. For the combined NIRSpec/NIRCam measurements a third still fainter target may need to be used. The observed PSF will also vary between measurements as the alignment state is improved during commissioning however we expect this to be less of an impact to precision.
The exact timing of ice observations will be coordinated with the wavefront team during OTE commissioning. Nominally observations should be made at regular intervals no closer together than 2 days. Observations will be timed to occur during the analysis periods in OTE commissioning. Table 1 lists a possible timeline of the ice monitoring observations. Please note that this is only a ‘suggested’ schedule of observations, and can be adjusted as needed. Some OTE phases have multiple possible PMSA states, depending on when observations are made. Target selection should be made accordingly. Where possible Observations should be made during ground analysis periods within OTE activities. Activities with specified Ground Analysis periods in the timeline are noted with an ‘*’ in the nominal observation plan.
Table 1: Nominal Ice Monitoring Observation Sequence Observation Est time OTE CAR PMSA state (initial) PMSA state (end) NC 1 (pre FSM heater shutoff) L~44 *OTE-04: WF - Segment ID - Ground Analysis PMSA unstacked initial deployed positions. NC 2 (post FSM heater shutoff) L~49 *OTE-09: WF - Image Stacking-1(Incoherent) PMSA unstacked large image array PMSA stacked, unphased
NC 3 (post FSM heater shutoff) L~52 *OTE-10: WF - SIAF Update (NRC, FGS) PMSA stacked, unphased PMSA stacked, unphased
NC 4 (post FSM heater shutoff) L~55 *OTE-12: WF - Coarse Phasing 1 PMSA stacked with an A seg kicked/guiding PMSA stacked with an A segment kicked/guiding
NC 5 (post FSM heater shutoff) L~65 *OTE-17: WF - Image Stacking-2 PMSA stacked w/ a segment kicked/guiding PMSA stacked with a segment kicked out for guiding
NC 6 (post FSM heater shutoff) L~69 *OTE-21: WF - Single Field Fine Phasing 2 PMSA stacked and phased PMSA stacked and phased
NC 7 (post FSM heater shutoff) L~75 OTE-29: WF - MIMF Measurement-1 PMSA stacked and phased PMSA stacked and phased
NC 8 & NS 1 (pre state 4 trans) L~85 OTE-26: WF Sensing (every 2 days) PMSA stacked and phased PMSA stacked and phased
NC 9 & NS 2 (pre-CCC opening) L~94 MIRI-005:MIRI Detector Anneal (1st instance) PMSA stacked and phased PMSA stacked and phased
* Note: If there is an issue with the pre-heater shutoff measurement, a contingency measurement can be implimented. This is in the APT as Observation #10: NC (Contingency pre FSM heater shutoff) PMSA unstacked initial deployed positions.
The procedure for executing Ice Monitoring observations must include coordination with the Timeline Coordinator, NIRCam and NIRSpec instrument teams, MOM, Project Science team and Wavefront team.
The equivalent width (EW) of the 3.1µm water ice feature will be measured for each observation and the differential measurements will be used to determine the rate of ice accumulation. If projected EOL 3.1µm equivalent width is beyond the contamination control plan requirements, the Anomaly Response Team will decide what contingency activities should be pursued per the Cooldown Plan (JWST-PLAN-034396).
APT/OSS Proposal Implementation:
TARGET: Observe spectrally featureless stars. The same target should be used for each set of observations. Below are identified potential targets depending on the PSMA status during the observations. All targets are selected to be relatively close either to the northern CVZ (18h, +66 33 38.552) or Southern CVZ (6h, -66 33 38.552). This distance is noted by the ‘Angle’ value in the table below.
Targets for observations with an unstacked PSMA (G2V stars) ID Angle Vmag Kmag RA Dec type HD 28701 9.298 7.87 6.284 4 25 45.85 -69 59 37.3 G2V HD 38973 13.444 6.63 5.220 5 46 27.19 -53 13 9.6 G2V HD 17216 19.488 7.44 5.788 2 35 1.81 -82 14 9.7 G2V HD 168009 21.453 6.3 4.756 18 15 32.46 +45 12 33.5 G2V
Targets for observations with a stacked PSMA (G2V stars): ID Angle Vmag Kmag RA Dec Spect type HD 268698 6.788 11.64 10.007 4 52 0.42 -68 42 4.8 G2V HD 270592 9.136 11.37 9.523 4 36 0.52 -72 1 3.0 G2V TYC-8558-11-1 12.096 10.7 9.247 7 9 25.58 -57 30 8.8 G2V BD +86 248 20.2 11.10 9.639 16 17 51.59 +86 21 7.0 G2V BD +86 189 22.516 11.10 9.531 13 8 54.00 +85 39 7.3 G2V BD +45 2829 22.623 11.4 9.781 19 5 12.49 +45 39 54.1 G2V GCRV-21765 2.324 13.42 13.5 5 49 0.55 -64 32 2.4 A0V EUVE J0502-62.4 7.435 15.90 15.220 5 2 0.43 -62 28 0.6 QSO (G2V) Final choice of target should be determined by OTE commissioning target requirements.
NIRCam Observation Setup Details LED Functionality: None
Ice Measurement –Images: NIRCam Engineering Imaging Template Module=A, RAPID, NGROUPS=5, NINTS=10, SubGrsm256 Filters: LW = F322W2 LongPupil=GRISMR
Module=A, Filters: F322W2
NIRSpec Observation Setup Details NIRSpec IFU Spectroscopy Grating/Filter: PRISM/Clear Readout Pattern: NRS Rapid, NGROUPS=5 NINTS=1 Dither Pattern: 4-Point Nod Total Dithers: 4, Total Integrations (w/ Dithers): 4
ACTIVITY EXECUTION METHOD: OSS commanding OTE
PRE-REQUISITES AND DEPENDENCIES: Requires successful completion of CAR_NIRCAM-002 and WFS&C/OTE CAR-066, Image Mosaic. As this activity is occurring during OTE commissioning the state of the telescope will be changing throughout execution. Stage 1: NIRCam temperature <85K Stage 2: NIRCam temperature <85K, OTE-CAR 194 (Image stack 1) executed Stage 3: NIRCam temperature <85K, OTE-CAR 194 (Image stack 1) executed, NIRSpec at operational temperature, NIRSpec CAR 20 (post-MIMF focus adjustment) executed
CRITICAL START WINDOW? No IF YES, NO-LATER-THAN START TIME: N/A
REAL-TIME CONTACT REQUIRED? No
DURATION: APT-based durations suggests all observations will take a total of 5.67 hours with APT overheads (as of APT version 2020.1.2). This activity will include nine NIRCam observations and two NIRSpec observations. Note that the readiness of the OTE will drive the timing of observations.
DATA REQUIREMENTS: Engineering telemetry data and science data. APT science data volume estimate is ~25 GB.
ANALYSIS & EXPECTED RESULTS: Each observation will be analyzed for the equivalent width of the 3.1 µm water ice feature. The change in EWs will be calculated to determine if there is water ice accumulation during the monitoring period. Estimated thicknesses of water ice will be calculated through comparison with models. These observations will also characterize the non-contamination based changes that occur during instrument cooldown (e.g PSF changes, backgrounds, etc). In the low likelihood event of significant ice accumulation, then a possible decontamination process would involve heating the SIs with their contamination control heaters to release the accumulated contamination and then re-cool.
IS YOUR INSTRUMENT DRIVING TELESCOPE POINTING? Yes IS THIS ACTIVITY PREFERABLY DONE IN PARALLEL? No
COMMENTS: This activity will have 9 NIRCam observations and 2 NIRSpec observations. The timing must be coordinated with the wavefront team. For contingencies see the Cooldown Plan, JWST-PLAN-034396.
APPLICABLE COMMISSIONING OBJECTIVE (note: commissioning objectives are out of date and are retained for historical information only.)
AUTHOR/TELEPHONE/EMAIL: Erin Smith; 301-286-7793; erin.c.smith@nasa.gov John Stansberry; 410-338-2442; jstans@stsci.edu Doug Kelly ; 520-621-8433 ; dkelly@as.arizona.edu Torsten Boeker; 410-338-2467; boeker@stsci.edu

InvestigatorAddress.Institution: Space Telescope Science Institute - ESA - JWST

This object has a similarly-bright neighbor 4" away that is very poorly placed for the expected epoch (mid-late Mar, 2022) of the observations that use it.
Also, it's in the south, but for 2 of the 3 observations currently using it (7, 8, 9) OTE stuff will probably be in the north.

No spectral type. SIMBAD says it's a star mis-classified as a QSO in some references. Description field here was set to Quasar. Not sure why this target is in this program.

K=4.7 G5, unkown class, very close to solar metallicity.

ObservationGroup.Label: Post OTE-04 NIRCam pointing and background check
ObservationGroup.Comments:
PCS_Mode = COARSE OTE is in initial deployed configuration
Work w/ WF team to pick a PMSA image for use in the first 2 groups of observations (this folder, and the "Pre FSM heater off NIRCam with Beam Probing" folder), and to adjust Offset SRs and/or target RA/Dec to place the target appropriatedly on the detectors.

Observation.Label: Pointing Pre-Check
Observation.Comments: The Offset SR is intended to ~position "the target" in the middle of A3.

Observation.Label: Bgrd Levels Sub256 Pre-Check
Observation.Comments: No Offset SR here - want to get a measure of sky + FSM emission background levels, so in some sense it's preferable not to have the PMSA image(s) on the detector. Of course an Offset may actually have to be added to achieve that.

Observation.Label: Star Levels Sub256 Pre-Check
Observation.Comments:
Aperture PA range 190 - 210 is about right for late Jan, early Feb for HD 84406.
Offset SR, which will need to be checked/updated prior to execution w/ help from the WF team, is intended to get the desired PMSA image into the SUB256 FOV.

Observation.Label: Bgrd Levels Sub64 Pre-Check
Observation.Comments:
Aperture PA range 190 - 210 is about right for late Jan, early Feb for HD 84406.
Sub64 is used because this is intended to provide a measurement of the background DN/s in case the background is really high. No Offset SR included - don't want a PMSA image in the FOV since it will swamp the backgrounds from sky + FSM. Might have to ADD an Offset SR in order to make sure we don't get a PMSA image in the subarray.

ObservationGroup.Label: Post OTE-04 NIRCam with Beam Probing
ObservationGroup.Comments:
Observation 1 is as originally planned, subgrism256 on module A.
Beam probing of different points on the NIRCam POM was added April, 2021, in observations 22 - 26. Observations 1 AND 22 - 26 are now ALL to be executed prior to the FSM Heater turn-off decision (i.e. that group is now NRC-35, iteration #1).
Note that observation 24 (Mod-B GrismR subarray) must be reprocessed in APT, and pointing verified/updated, after implementation of https://jira.stsci.edu/browse/APT-92467 , expected to be ready in APT 2021.2.
PCS Mode=COARSE SRs are required - FGS will have no guiding capability when these observations are executed.

Observation.Label: LW Grism Ice Monitor #1 Mod-A 256 subarray
Observation.Comments:
This observation is to be taken as soon as possible in the OTE sequence (when NIRCAM <85K and the long-wavelength channel is functional) This observation will be taken with the FSM heater on and the telescope segments un-stacked.
This observation is only appropriate for early OTE commissioning, with un-stacked PMSA images, or for during OTE Segment Image Array observations. A subarray is used because we expect high background from the warm FSM baffle.
A 2-row mosaic is used in order to make sure we get the star image in the subarray FOV in at least 1 pointing. This assumes that the slew to the target is no worse than about 4" off the true position.
An Offset special requirement is included as a way to put the image of one segment at the desired field point in the subarray. The values entered are notional and will need to be updated once the configuration of the PMSA images is known.
PA range~190 -- ~210 is appropriate for c. 2022 Jan 30 for HD 84406.

Observation.Label: Module A GrismR -V2 1 column 2 pts
Observation.Comments:
PA range~190 -- ~210 is appropriate for c. 2022 Jan 30 for HD 84406.
The Offset special requirement has 2 purposes:
1) As a way to put the image of one segment at the desired field point in the subarray. The values entered are notional and would need to be updated once the configuration of the PMSA images is known.
2) To place the target PMSA image near the -V2 edge of the A-LW detector.

Observation.Label: Module A GrismC +V2 1 pt
Observation.Comments:
PA range~190 -- ~210 is appropriate for c. 2022 Jan 30 for HD 84406.
The Offset special requirement has 2 purposes:
1) As a way to put the image of one segment at the desired field point in the subarray. The values entered are notional and would need to be updated once the configuration of the PMSA images is known.
2) To place the target PMSA image near the+-V2 edge of the A-LW detector.

Observation.Label: Module B GrismR 256 subarray
Observation.Comments:
PA range~190 -- ~210 is appropriate for c. 2022 Jan 30 for HD 84406.
Note that observation 24 must be reprocessed and pointing verified after implementation of https://jira.stsci.edu/browse/APT-92467 , expected to be ready in APT 2021.2.
The offset SR included on observation 24 is intended to place the target at *approximately* the correct location for the SUBGRISM256 subarray on B5, which is near the +V3 edge. Once the APT ticket above is implemented, the subarray aperture will be correctly displayed.
The Offset special requirement is also included as a way to put the image of one segment at the desired field point in the subarray. The values entered are notional and would need to be updated once the configuration of the PMSA images is known.
NOTE: A target with K~3.5 is desired for this observation, but not included in the target list. Contact Randy Kimble and/or Erin Smith for an appropriate target prior to executing this observation.

Observation.Label: Module B GrismR +V2 1 column 2 pts
Observation.Comments:
PA range~190 -- ~210 is appropriate for c. 2022 Jan 30 for HD 84406.
The Offset special requirement has 2 purposes:
1) As a way to put the image of one segment at the desired field point in the subarray. The values entered are notional and would need to be updated once the configuration of the PMSA images is known.
2) To place the target PMSA image near the +V2 edge of the B-LW detector.

Observation.Label: Module B GrismC -V2 1 pt
Observation.Comments:
PA range~190 -- ~210 is appropriate for c. 2022 Jan 30 for HD 84406.
The Offset special requirement has 2 purposes:
1) As a way to put the image of one segment at the desired field point in the subarray. The values entered are notional and would need to be updated once the configuration of the PMSA images is known.
2) To place the target PMSA image near the -V2 edge of the B-LW detector.

ObservationGroup.Label: Post-FSM heater off NIRCam Observations
ObservationGroup.Comments: # L+d PCS Mode OTE ------------------------- 2 43 COARSE Deploy 3 47 COARSE SIA-1 4 50 COARSE SIA-1 5 54 COARSE IS-1 6 57 COARSE IS-1 7 67 TRACK FP-1 8 77 TRACK MIMF-1 9 98 Fine MIMF

Observation.Label: LW Grism Ice Monitor #2
Observation.Comments:
Expected OTE state is DEPLOY.
The Offset special requirement is included in order to put the image of one segment at the desired field point on the detector, near the nomal X position for F322W2 + GrismR, and ~20" onto the detector in Y. The values entered are notional and will need to be updated once the configuration of the PMSA images is known.

Observation.Label: LW Grism Ice Monitor #3
Observation.Comments:
Expected OTE state is SIA-1, but with no corrections to the PMSA PSFs.
The Offset special requirement is included in order to put the images of the PMSAs at the extreme V3 positions on the detector so that spectra can be extracted from both. The -V3 image should be positioned in Y at the same place as the spectrum taken in Observation #2. The Offset SR will need to be checked/updated prior to execution.

Observation.Label: LW Grism Ice Monitor #4
Observation.Comments:
Expected OTE state is SIA-1, with only initial corrections to the PMSA PSFs.
The Offset special requirement is included in order to put the images of the PMSAs at the extreme V3 positions on the detector so that spectra can be extracted from both. The positions of those segments should be the same as in Obs. 3. The Offset SR will need to be checked/updated with help from the WF team prior to execution.

Observation.Label: LW Grism Ice Monitor #5
Observation.Comments:
Expected OTE state is IS-1, so no Offset SR is needed.
A Guide Star Photometry override file may be needed for this observation if the PCS Mode is switched to TRACK. Consult with the WF team prior to executing this observation.

Observation.Label: LW Grism Ice Monitor #6
Observation.Comments:
Expected OTE state is IS-1, so no Offset SR is needed.
A Guide Star Photometry override file may be needed for this observation if the PCS Mode is switched to TRACK. Consult with the WF team prior to executing this observation.

Observation.Label: LW Grism Ice Monitor #7
Observation.Comments:
Expected OTE state is FP-1, so no Offset SR is needed.
Update PA Range SR to maximize separation between target and 4" neighbor in X-dispersion if target is GCRV-21765. Actually probably prefer to find a star near CVZ-S to minimize slew from prior OTE activity.
A Guide Star Photometry override file may be needed for this observation. Consult with the WF team prior to executing this observation.

Observation.Label: NIRSpec Ice Monitoring Observation (w NC#8)
Observation.Comments:
This observation is to be taken after the FSM heater has been turned off, but prior to the State 4 decision point. Observation must be coordinated with OTE and wavefront activities, potentially occuring during WF analysis periods.
Expected OTE state is MIMF-1, so no Offset SR is needed.
Please note: the 1-1.8 micron region will saturate. THe wavelength range of interest is 2.5 to 3 microns, so this is acceptable.
A Guide Star Photometry override file may be needed for this observation. Consult with the WF team prior to executing this observation.

Observation.Label: LW Grism Ice Monitor #8
Observation.Comments:
Expected OTE state is FP-1, so no Offset SR is needed.
Update PA Range SR to maximize separation between target and 4" neighbor in X-dispersion if target is GCRV-21765. Actually probably prefer to find a star near CVZ-S to minimize slew from prior OTE activity.
A Guide Star Photometry override file may be needed for this observation. Consult with the WF team prior to executing this observation.

Observation.Label: NIRSpec Ice Monitoring Observation (w NC#9)
Observation.Comments:
This observation is to be taken after the FSM heater has been turned off, after the State 4 decision point, but before the MIRI cover opening. Observation must be coordinated with OTE and wavefront activities, potentially occuring during WF analysis periods.
Nominally this observation should take place during an analysis period during MIRI-005: MIRI Detector Anneal (First Instance)
This observation is only appropriate for OTE commissioning, with stacked PMSA images.
Please note: the 1-1.8 micron region will saturate. THe wavelength range of interest is 2.5 to 3 microns, so this is acceptable.

Observation.Label: LW Grism Ice Monitor #9
Observation.Comments:
Expected OTE state is FP-1, so no Offset SR is needed.
Update PA Range SR to maximize separation between target and 4" neighbor in X-dispersion if target is GCRV-21765. Actually probably prefer to find a star near CVZ-S to minimize slew from prior OTE activity.
A Guide Star Photometry override file may be needed for this observation. Consult with the WF team prior to executing this observation.
